about: I recently finished grad school at USC with a MS in computer science. My undergraduate degree was in aerospace engineering.

I started grad school with an open mind about what I wanted to focus on. After exploring a variety of topics, I think pursuing a career in systems would be most fulfilling for me. The classes I've taken the most away from were two OS classes and two networking classes. Working with systems, or low level langues in general, feels a little like pulling the curtains back. Seeing how hardware and software work together to build something greater than their parts is what makes me interested in CS. I still have a lot to learn, and hopefully I'll be lucky enough to find a career where I can keep learning.

experience.title: Teaching Assistant
summary: Taught discrete math and algorithms (CSCI 107) in the fall of 2019.
Taught data structures and OO design (CSCI 104) from spring 2020 onward.
Designing programing homeworks/labs, writing grading tools, making content for weekly discussions, running labs, and of course hunting C++ bugs in office hours.

experience.title: Associate Engineer
summary: This was SpaceX's new grad program. I worked on the crew capsule actuators systems that moved the seats with the interior mechanisms team.
Design and analysis of various metal flight parts related to the seat actuators using first principles, CAD, and FEA.
Built test hardware for actuator vibration and thermal testing. Performed some simple modal and thermal analysis to inform these designs.
Got some experience running tests, handling transducer hardware, labview, and excell + python to process data.

experience.company: UW Human Ability and Engineering Lab
experience.title: Undergrad Researcher
summary: Ankle foot orthoses (AFOs) are commonly perscribed to cerebral palsy patients to assist with walking.

Our goal was to build a simple deivce to quantify power loss and the efficiency of an AFO, then validate our deivce by comparing it to human data. I co-design and maufactured a test AFO and a fake-ankle type device to apply load to the AFO.
Recorded analog test data using an arduino C++ program and processed data with Matlab to attempt to quantify losses and user end power.

experience.title: Intern
summary: I worked with three other interns to study additively manufactured (metal 3d printed) lattice structures. The ability to fabricate these web-like volumes is pretty new, and engineers are just begining to design parts with lattice structural/flow components.
These structures are difficult to analyze with FEA. Our goal was to quantify their physical properties (mechanical, thermal, and fluid) for use in analysis.

We designed and conducted thermal and flow tests to record pressure and temp data, similar to how they might be used in a heat exchanger. We also built lattice coupons to test in torsion/tension/shear. I used a bit of python to handle the data.

details.text: JOS is a exokernel OS built for x86 arcitecture.
The project touched on the boot process and file system, but the brunt of it had to do with the virtual memory subsystem.

I thought JOS was a fun next step after Weenix because much of the project revolved specifics of x86 hardware. We got to interact with the hardware while working with page tables, supporting multiple CPU cores, preemption/context switching, handling traps/interrupts.

Some other cool features include a debugging tool to trace the stack, shell commands, a IPC system, and a unix style fork(). Our class version of JOS also included a optional extension for a networking stack, which I'm still playing with.
Our class had access to a testbed consisting of a bunch of computers, where I simluated different topology/traffic scenarios.
Wrote a daemon that monitored network interfaces for high traffic events, including simulated DDoS attacks.

Tested the same DDoS attack with a anycast setup. Modified the daemon to react to attacks via either IP filtering at the attacked site (in the case where the attackers query name is known) or modifying BGP data to double append the AS to the path to shift traffic away.

Also tested a deploying a scrubber service on a seperate machine to handle DDoS attacks. This time the monitoring daemon modified BGP data to redirect traffic to the scrubber, which forwarded only valid queries to the server.
Worked with two pals on a semester long project building out a single threaded Unix 6th edition based kernel running in QEMU.
We implemented processes and thread control, a virtual file system abstraction layer, and finaly a virtual memory system. Started by initializing the idle process all the way to running user code.
Implemented process and thread data structures, a FIFO scheduler, kernel level mutex, virtual file system, Unix system calls, shadow objects and an on-demand paged virtual memory!
Applied cool data science concepts like cross validation, bootstrap, monte carlo simulation, regularization, SMOTE, active learning and self training.
Worked with KNN, linear/logistic regression, bayesian discriminant analysis, lasso/ridge regression, PCR, SVM/SVCs, random forests, and K-means clustering.
Practiced working with diverse datasets and goals, ie time series data, imbalanced data, multi-class and multi-label problems.
Web Development Class Project. Built a live news Web App that fetched data from various APIs through a cloud hosted backend.
html/css/js, python Flask backend hosten on AWS
React frontend, node.js backend, GCP hosted
Android App (Java), node.js backend, GCP hosted
I designed, built, and open sourced an Arduino driven music visualizer with parts that come in under $30. Still works too!
An 8x8 array of individually addressed LEDs behind a black acrylic sheet form a 64 pixel ‚Äúscreen‚Äù.
Designed a custom PCB, 3D printed housing, and C++ software with a few different animations.
An integrated analog mic samples audio which is FFT‚Äôed into eight frequency bins spanning audible sound. Bin data is used to animate the screen.

details.title: Languages
details.text: I like C, C++, Javascript, Python, Bash, Java, and Matlab/Simulink.

details.title: Software Development
details.text: I've worked with git, gdb, make, cmake, valgrind, and GTest. I'm most confortable working with linux.

details.title: Operating Sytems
details.text: I'm farmiliar with OS fundementals like address translation, paging, locking, and file systems. I know a bit about computer hardware (the MMU, TLB, CPU caches, memory, disks) and particularly how the parts interact with the OS. I've also studied some less traditional types of OSes too, like exokernels and virtual machines.

details.title: Networking
details.text: I'm comfortable with the theory behind IP, transport protocols like TCP/UDP, and link layer protocols like wifi/ethernet, and BGP. I've also studied some other neat stuff like onion routing and cluster computing.

details.title: Data Science
details.text: I've used pandas, seaborn, sklearn, weka, and google Colab.

details.title: Web Development
details.text: Farmiliar with html/css/md, JQuery, Bootstrap, React, node.js, flask, browser debugging, and AWS/GCP cloud products.

details.title: Algorithms
details.text: Farmiliar with graph algorithms, principle component analysis, dynamic/linear programming methods, and applying complexity analysis to design code that scales.

details.title: Data Science
details.text: I'm comfortable with the theory behind all the ML algorithms and tools listed up in the projects section, as well as a few others like Hidden Markov Models and neural nets.

details.title: Simulation
details.text: I've built and animated fun physics simulations, and done more pracical stuff like design PID systems with bode/nyquist plots and test them with simulink.

details.title: Signal Processing
details.text: I've processed audio with Fourier analysis algorithms and worked with real world data collection.

details.title: Design
details.text: I've used CAD software for mechanical design (Solidworks, NX) and electrical design (KiCad), plus Anysis for FEA.

details.title: Mechatronics
details.text: I've incorporated microcontrollers/RPis, LiPos power systems, brushed/brushless motors, RC receiver/transmitters, and other hardware into projects.

details.title: Manufacturing
details.text: Farmiliar with GD&T drafting, metal/plastic 3D printing, THT/SMD soldering, and 2 axis mills/lathes.
